awd_titl_txt: CAREER:RNA conformational dynamics in the regulation of microRNA biogenesis
awd_abstract_narration:
RNA is one of the three major biological macromolecules that are essential for all known forms of life (along with DNA and proteins).  While for many years RNA was believed to have only three major roles in the cell, it is now known that the roles adopted by RNA are much broader and interesting.  MicroRNAs are a class of evolutionarily conserved, small noncoding RNAs. They regulate more than 60% of all protein genes, and serve as critical regulators in all biological processes. Due to their central role in gene regulation, microRNAs themselves are tightly regulated. This project will investigate how conformational dynamics in two distinct microRNAs control recognition of specific protein cofactors to regulate their processing pathways. Results of this project will provide important mechanistic insights into the regulation of these essential gene regulators. This project will expand the current knowledge of RNA-protein interactions and deepen the understanding of the functional roles of RNA conformational dynamics in biology. Research and education will be integrated in this project to support scientific training and education of undergraduate and graduate students as well as underrepresented high-school students in STEM principles. An on-campus program will be developed for high-school students featuring an annual scientific forum and summer research internships. Outreach activities to local high schools will be carried out to develop innovative STEM teaching approaches.

MicroRNA biogenesis is a dynamic and regulated process. During the canonical biogenesis pathway, the apical-loop regions of primary and precursor microRNAs play critical regulatory roles. However, these RNA elements are highly flexible and have evaded high-resolution structural study by conventional structural biology techniques. Recent developments in nucleic acid NMR spectroscopy, including those from the PI, have opened new avenues to characterize complex conformational dynamics and transitions in highly flexible RNAs. This project will further develop and apply these NMR methods, together with biochemical and computational approaches, to understand the mechanism by which microRNA biogenesis is regulated via specific RNA-protein interactions. Using microRNA-1 and microRNA-21 as model systems, this project will visualize RNA conformational dynamics in microRNA precursors and elucidate the structural and molecular basis for the regulatory roles of protein cofactors in microRNA biogenesis. Results will be used to evaluate the central hypothesis of this project that the apical-loop regions of primary and precursor microRNAs dynamically sample distinct conformations for protein recognition and that these dynamics may be tuned to affect protein-RNA interactions to direct biogenesis pathways.

por.por_cntn:
MicroRNAs are evolutionarily conserved small noncoding RNAs that serve as critical gene regulators in many aspects of biological processes, where more than 60% of all protein genes are estimated to be regulated by microRNAs at the post-transcriptional levels. Due to their essential roles in gene regulation, microRNAs are tightly controlled, and abnormal microRNA expressions have been linked to dysregulations in biology. Hence, intense research has focused on understanding the mechanisms via which microRNAs are regulated. Over the past decades, diverse protein factors have been discovered to regulate various microRNA biogenesis steps. In these studies, it has often been perceived that protein regulators act on primary and precursor microRNAs to direct the outcome of microRNA biogenesis. However, the functional roles of primary and precursor microRNAs in modulating microRNA biogenesis remain elusive. This can be largely attributed to limited high-resolution structural and dynamic knowledge of these microRNA intermediates, as they are often too flexible to be characterized using conventional structural biology approaches. In this project, we have developed and applied state-of-the-art solution NMR techniques and other biophysical and biochemical methods to overcome some of these experimental hurdles for visualizing the conformational dynamics of these highly flexible RNAs. By integrating these physical and chemical techniques with functional characterizations, we have unveiled a new protein-independent mechanism for microRNA regulation, in which a microRNA processing intermediate can tune its dynamic conformational ensemble in response to sense environmental and cellular stimuli for directing the outcome of microRNA biogenesis. This project has provided the microRNA field with a new paradigm for the mechanistic understanding of the regulation of miRNA biogenesis. It has also provided the field of RNA biophysics with new techniques for studying dynamic structural ensembles of RNA.

 

During the project, we have extensively integrated research and education to support scientific education and training of the next generation of scientists in the STEM field. We have trained four undergraduate, four graduate students, and a postdoctoral fellow in the PI?s lab on this project. In addition, we have also involved junior researchers in the scientific community. We have hosted 13 high school student researchers working in the PI?s lab to gain hands-on research experiences and participate in scientific events. We have further hosted 30 high school students and their science teachers from underrepresented STEM high school in rural North Carolina to visit the PI?s lab and the university and have invited four of these high school students and their teacher to attend scientific conferences on RNA biology and interact and network with nationally and internationally renowned scientists. By partnering with the university, we have established a scientific forum focusing on RNA biology, which has engaged more than 100 high school students from low-incoming families in neighboring counties. These comprehensive lab and community outreach activities have not only gained public support but also encouraged student participation in STEM, enabling us to actively contribute to the diverse and vibrant generations of scientists in STEM.
